 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
1. 
to  the  Lao  People's  Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR)  for  the  Strengthening  Technical  and 
Vocational Education and Training Project. 
 
The project seeks to improve the quality of, and access to, formal technical and vocational 
2. 
education  and  training  (TVET)  in  the  Lao  PDR,  focusing  on  certificate  and  diploma  programs. 
Quality  improvements  include  developing  skill  standards,  improving  curricula,  and  training 
teachers  in  four  priority  skill  areas:  (i)  construction  and  building  trades,  (ii)  mechanical  and 
machinery  maintenance  and  repair,  (iii)  furniture-making,  and  (iv)  basic  business.  Access  and 
equity  will  be  enhanced  through  the  introduction  of  a  voucher  assistance  training  scheme  and 
construction of dormitories. A key project focus is on increasing private involvement in TVET and 
achieving greater alignment between TVET and labor market needs.1 The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.   
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The Lao PDR economy has been growing strongly, with gross domestic product growth 
expected  to  reach  7.5%  in  2010  and  average  7.8%  during  2011–2015.  The  government  is 
seeking to sustain strong economic growth to meet its poverty-related Millennium Development 
Goals  by  2015  and  graduate  from  least-developed  country  status  by  2020.  Limited  human 
resources,  weak  capacity,  and  skills  shortages  represent  critical  binding  constraints  for  the 
country. Absorbing the growing number of school leavers and providing the skills needed in the 
fast-growing economy represent emerging challenges and pose risks for the country's long-term 
development prospects. The labor market assessment identifies skill shortages across several 
sectors, including construction, furniture-making, and automobile and machinery repair. 
 
4. 
The  TVET  sector  should  play  an  important  role  in  training  skilled  workers  for  industry 
and  in  meeting  labor  market  needs.  However,  for  a  variety  of  reasons,  the  sector  is  poorly 
positioned  to  contribute  to  either  of  these.  The  sector  and  labor  market  assessments  indicate 
that (i) TVET enrolments are declining in high-demand skill areas and where skill shortages are 
greatest (e.g., construction), and (ii) only a small proportion of firms recruit workers directly from 
TVET institutions and few firms have any relationship with TVET institutions.  
 
5. 
The role of the TVET sector in providing skilled workers to industry is limited by the lack 
of alignment between the skills required in the labor market and those produced by the TVET 
sector, and to the poor quality of training. These are in turn explained by shortages of qualified 
and trained teachers, the absence of teaching aids, and limited practical skills among teaching 
staff. TVET curricula and programs are outdated and involve little practical training. Many TVET 
institutions lack modern facilities and equipment. Much of the training offered in the TVET sector 
is  not  relevant  to  labor  market  needs.  Despite  the  existence  of  the  National  Training  Council 
(NTC),  the  TVET  sector  public–private  coordinating  body,  linkages  between  the  public  and 
private  sectors  are  weak.  Private  sector  involvement  in  TVET,  including  finance,  strategy  and 
curriculum development, and delivery of training, can be increased. Few private institutions offer 
programs in traditional trades.  
 
6. 
Although  each  province  of  the  Lao  PDR  has  a  TVET  institution,  travel  distances  for 
students can be significant. The lack of clean, safe, and culturally appropriate accommodation 
can also act as a barrier to TVET study, particularly for girls and students from ethnic groups. 
Female enrollment is low in traditional trade areas, despite good employment opportunities and 

                                                 
1   Project  preparation  was  carried  out  through  ADB.  2009.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  Lao  People's  Democratic 

Republic for Strengthening Technical and Vocational Education and Training Project. Manila (TA 7299-LAO). 

 

 

 relatively  good  wages.  Women  and  ethnic  groups  in  rural  areas  face  particular  barriers  to 
access due to travel distance and lack of student accommodation. Trainees from the nonformal 
sector  face  academic  barriers  in  accessing  formal  TVET,  due  to  the  lack  of  a  national 
qualifications framework and bridging programs. 
 
TVET  system  governance  is  weak,  as  is  the  management  of  TVET  institutions.  The 
7. 
government's TVET strategy and master plan identify a need to reform the policy and regulatory 
framework for TVET. The current supply-side-based funding system and inflexible employment 
arrangements restrict the ability of institutions to manage themselves efficiently and to change 
program  offerings  to  reflect  emerging  areas  of  demand.  The  capacity  of  the  Ministry  of 
Education (MOE) and the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare (MOLSW) to manage a reformed 
TVET  system  is  weak,  and  the  two  ministries  need  to  be  more  coordinated.  A  labor  market 
information  system  (LMIS)  is  needed  to  identify  areas  of  labor  market  demand  and  skill 
shortages;  and  support  the  TVET  system  in  responding  to  labor  market  needs  and  offering 
potential students information on opportunities available in TVET.    
 
8. 
Because  skill  shortages  are  a  key  constraint  on  the  country's  development,  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) involvement in the TVET sector is strongly justified. Vocational training 
has a significant impact on both productivity and poverty reduction.2 TVET is a key focus of the 
government's  Education  Sector  Development  Framework  (ESDF),  and  the  government  has 
developed a TVET strategy and master plan. The country strategy and program midterm review 
(August  2009)  identifies  a  need  for  a  gradual  shift  in  ADB’s  sector  assistance  emphasis  to 
strengthening postbasic education, including TVET and higher education.3 The project is included 
in the 2009–2011 country operations business plan for the country.4  
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

9. 
The expected impact of the project is a more highly skilled and diverse workforce in Lao 
PDR. The performance target is that the number of workers in the labor force with formal TVET 
qualifications  increases  by  25%  (50%  for  females)  from  2011  to  2021.  The  project’s  expected 
outcome  is  an  accessible  formal  vocational  training  system  that  is  more  responsive  to  labor 
market needs.    
 
C. 

Outputs 

The project will focus on certificate and diploma training in four priority skill areas with an 
10. 
identified  labor  demand:  (i)  construction  and  building  trades,  (ii)  mechanical  and  machinery 
maintenance and repair, (iii) furniture-making, and (iv) basic business. These priority skill areas 
were  selected  based  on  the  findings  of  the  2010  labor  market  assessment.  This  assessment 
lists and sets out the selection criteria for the four priority skill areas.5 The project will focus on 
seven  public  TVET  institutions,  four  private  TVET  institutions  and  the  Vocational  Education 
Development  Center  (VEDC).  These  entities  will  receive  a  range  of  assistance  under  the 
project,  including  teacher  training,  new  curricula,  and  management  training.  The  seven  public 
and  four  private  TVET  institutions  will  also  be  eligible  to  enroll  students  under  the  voucher 
assistance  training  program.  The  seven  public  TVET  institutions  and  VEDC  will  receive 
equipment  and  facility  upgrades.  The  selection  of  priority  skill  areas  identifies  the  institutions 
involved in the project and the criteria used to select them.6   
 
11. 
The project will deliver five outputs: (i) improved quality of TVET, (ii) increased and more 
equitable  access  to  TVET,  (iii)  increased  private  sector  involvement  in  TVET  strategy  and

delivery, (iv) strengthened management and governance of the TVET system, and (v) effective 
project management and implementation. 
 

1. 

Improved Quality of TVET 

 
12. 
The project will support improvements in the quality of formal TVET in the four priority skill 
areas by (i) developing national skill standards; (ii) improving curriculum and TVET packages based 
on  national  skill  standards;  (iii)  enhancing  teacher  standards  and  strengthening  TVET  preservice 
and  in-service  teacher  training;  (iv)  enhancing  career  counselling  and  vocational  guidance  at  the 
seven  public  and  the  four  private  TVET  institutions;  (v)  initiating  a  social  marketing  campaign  to 
promote TVET; and (vi) upgrading equipment and facilities at the seven public TVET institutions for 
their programs in the four priority skill areas, at the VEDC and at the Polytechnic College. 
 
13. 
Improve  institutional  performance.  The  project  will  develop  competency-based  skill 
standards  and  modernized  curricula  in  the  four  priority  skill  areas.  It  will  enhance  TVET  teacher 
professional  standards  for  teachers  across  all  skill  areas  to  better  identify  and  target  teacher 
professional  development.  Teacher  standards  will  provide  a  benchmark  against  which  to  assess 
student TVET teachers and those seeking employment as teachers. Standards will cover technical 
and pedagogical skills. The project will also improve preservice and in-service teacher training by 
strengthening the VEDC teaching staff, programs, and equipment and facilities.   
 
14. 
Conduct  social  marketing  campaign.  A  sustained  social  marketing  campaign  will  be 
initiated  to  improve  the  poor  public perception of  TVET  and  vocationally-oriented  occupations. 
This campaign, to be conducted with employers and TVET institutions, will seek to increase the 
number and quality of students in the TVET sector, and increase interest in vocational training 
among  females  and  ethnic  groups.  The  campaign  will  use  a  range  of  techniques,  including 
information provided by institutions and employers, job fairs, and television and radio dramas to 
highlight the many benefits of pursuing vocational training.    
 
15. 
Introduce  career  counselling  and  vocational  guidance.  To  complement  the  LMIS 
and  social  marketing  campaign,  the  project  will  train  teachers  and  develop  career  counselling 
and guidance materials for use in the seven public and four private TVET institutions to ensure 
that students are better informed about TVET career choices and opportunities.   
 
Upgrade  equipment  and  improve  facilities.  The  project's  investments  in  human 
16. 
resource  development  will  be  accompanied  by  equipment  and  facility  upgrades  at  the  seven 
public  TVET  institutions  and  VEDC.  One  further  public  TVET  institution  –  the  Polytechnic 
College – will receive funding to upgrade a specialist workshop required for project activities.  
 

Increased and More Equitable Access to TVET 

2. 
 
17. 
This output will increase access to formal certificate and diploma TVET for students from 
remote areas, including girls, by (i) providing training assistance vouchers to TVET trainees; (ii) 
increasing  access  for  students,  particularly  girls,  from  remote  areas  by  financing  the 
construction  of  student-friendly  dormitory  facilities;  and  (iii)  broadening  access  to  vocational 
training  by  supporting  a  review  of  TVET  certificate  entry  qualifications  to  reduce  academic 
barriers to training, and the development of new entry qualifications, procedures for recognizing 
prior learning, and special assistance programs.  
 
18. 
Provide  training  assistance  vouchers.  The  training  assistance  voucher  program  will 
provide tuition fee assistance and a stipend to cover living costs for students in the seven public 
and four private TVET institutions. To be eligible to receive the voucher, a student must (i) be 
enrolled in a certificate or diploma program at one of the seven public TVET institutions or four 
private TVET institutions in one of the four priority skill areas, (ii) be at least 16 years old, and 
(iii)  have  attended  elementary  school  or  have  recent  employment  experience.  A  total  of  4,800 

 

 vouchers will be offered over the project period. MOE will select the voucher recipients using a 
transparent  process  outlined  in  the  project  administration  manual  (PAM).7  At  least  25%  of  the 
vouchers will be allocated to females and 20% to students from ethnic groups. Female voucher-
recipient  graduates  will  be  assisted  in  securing  employment  through  the  payment  of  a  wage 
subsidy  to  their  employer,  covering  approximately  30%  of  the  graduate's  starting  salary.  The 
wage subsidy will last for 6 months.  
 
19. 
Enhance access for women and ethnic groups. The project will construct or refurbish 
2,200 student-friendly dormitory places to improve access for female and ethnic students. The 
dormitories will be in the seven public TVET institutions and VEDC, with 50% of places reserved 
for women.     
 

3. 

Increased Private Sector Involvement in TVET Strategy and Delivery 

 
To  increase  private  sector  involvement  in  TVET  strategy  and  delivery,  the  project  will  
20. 
(i)  strengthen  NTC’s  permanent  office  and  increase  its  private  sector  focus,  (ii)  establish  or 
strengthen industry-based trade working groups (TWGs) for the four priority skill areas, (iii) establish 
advisory  boards  at  the  seven  public  TVET  institutions,  with  at  least  25%  private  sector  and  25% 
female  representation,  (iv)  introduce  a  contracting  scheme  with  private  firms  for  the  delivery  of 
training  to  teachers  and  students  in  specialist  skill  areas,  and  (v)  introduce  a  contracting  scheme 
with private TVET institutions to deliver training to students across a range of skill areas.   
 
Strengthen industry involvement in skill standards and curriculum. NTC's functions 
21. 
include providing strategic advice on TVET issues, coordinating with public and private training 
providers,  overseeing  the  development  of  TVET  standards  by  TWGs,  and  monitoring  training 
performance and examination standards.8 The project will carry out an organizational review to 
identify  structural  and  operational  changes  that  would  improve  NTC  functioning  and  increase 
the private sector's role across a range of functions. The project will also support the TWGs to 
increase  industry  involvement  in  the  development  of  skill  standards  and  curriculum  in  the  four 
priority skill areas.     
 
22. 
Introduce contracting programs with private firms and TVET institutions. The project 
will introduce two contracting programs to improve the relevance and responsiveness of the TVET 
system, and to allow the targeting of training to areas of skill shortage. The first will involve direct 
government  contracting  with  private  firms  for  the  delivery  of  training  to  TVET  students  and 
teachers in  specialist skill areas that require expensive equipment that  TVET institutions cannot 
afford  (e.g.,  mining  programs).  The  second  will  involve  direct  contracting  with  private  TVET 
institutions for the delivery of training in areas outside the four priority skill areas. In both cases, 
the government will pay a fixed amount per student for the delivery of training, with the payment 
being higher for women trainees. More than 6,700 students will be trained under these programs. 
Training  providers  (private  firms  and  private  TVET  institutions)  will  be  selected  for  these 
contracting programs using consultants' qualifications selection through lump sum contracting.   
 

Strengthened Management and Governance of the TVET System  

4. 
 
23. 
This output will strengthen management and governance of the TVET sector by (i) reviewing 
and  strengthening  the  policy  and  regulatory  framework  for  TVET,  including  increasing  flexibility  in 
employment arrangements for TVET teachers and introducing a unit cost funding system for TVET; 
(ii) improving quality assurance in the seven public TVET institutions, four private TVET institutions 
and VEDC; (iii) strengthening TVET information systems by developing an education management 
information  system,  including  design  and  system  development,  and  strengthening  capacity  to

operate  and  maintain  the  system;  (iv)  establishing  a  labor  market  information  system,  including 
design and system development, and strengthening capacity to operate and maintain the system; 
and  (v)  strengthening  the  capacity  of  management  in  the  MOE's  Technical  and  Vocational 
Education Department (TVED), VEDC and the seven public and four private TVET institutions. 
 
Strengthen  the  policy  and  regulatory  framework.  The  project  will  help  the 
24. 
government (i) design and implement a new unit-cost-based funding system and more flexible 
employment  arrangements  to  provide  TVET  institutions  with  greater  operating  flexibility,  and  
(ii)  provide  scope  for  TVET  institutions  to  offer  programs  that  are  more  relevant  to  the  labor 
market.  Both  of  these  reforms  represent  government  policy,  agreed  as  part  of  the  ESDF 
approved by the Prime Minister in January 2009.  The mechanism for introducing the unit cost-
based funding system will be aligned with the policies and timeline adopted by the government.   
 
Improve  information  on  the  labor  market  and  TVET  sector.  To  address  the  lack  of 
25. 
information on labor market demand and the TVET sector, the project will (i) establish an LMIS 
that  will  provide  information  to  MOLSW  and  MOE  on  labor  market  indicators  such  as  skill 
shortages  and  salaries  for  TVET-trained  workers,  and  (ii)  strengthen  the  TVET  education 
management  information  system.  MOE  will  use  LMIS  information  to  inform  funding  allocation 
decisions, and TVET institutions will use it to inform decisions on program and course offerings. 
Tracer studies will be undertaken as part of this work. The LMIS will be housed at MOLSW. The 
education  management  information  system  will  be  strengthened  to  include  a  wider  range  of 
information on the TVET sector and link nonfinancial and financial data on the education sector.  
 

Effective Project Management and Implementation Facilitated 

5. 
 
26. 
This  output  will  support:  (a)  the  establishment  of  facilities  and  systems  required  for 
effective project management and implementation; and (b) the development and implementation 
of a project monitoring and evaluation system, including preparation of required plans and data 
systems, the gender action plan (GAP), ethnic groups development plan, and baseline studies.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

The  direct  beneficiaries  of  the  project  will  be  the  20,000  and  more  students  who  will 
32. 
benefit  from  improvements  in  the  quality  of  TVET  education  and  increased  access  to  TVET 
resulting  from  initiatives  such  as  the  voucher  program,  dormitories,  and  skill  contracting 
programs. Over the course of the project, the voucher program will benefit 4,800 students, while 
the  two  contracting  programs  will  benefit  more  than  10,000  students.  The  additional  dormitory 
places will benefit 1,170 students. Female students and students from ethnic groups will capture 
a  significant  proportion  of  the  direct  benefits  due  to  the  project's  gender  and  ethnic  targets. 
Students in the public and private TVET institutions studying in the four priority skill areas and 
teacher  trainees  at  VEDC  will  also  benefit  from  better  instruction,  due  to  the  quality 
improvement  initiatives  that  are  a  key  part  of  the  project  design,  including  revised  curricula, 
upgraded facilities and equipment, and skill standards. Teachers and administrators will benefit 
from  the  extensive  training  and  mentoring  programs  provided  under  the  project.  Priority  skill 
areas and associated standards, training, and equipment have been chosen for their relevance 
to the Lao PDR economy and capacity.   
 
A. 

Economic and Financial 

33. 
The  direct  economic  benefits  from  the  project  are  derived  mainly  from  the  increased 
number  of  TVET  graduates  and  the  improved  labor  market  outcomes  from  TVET  programs. 
Four  main  categories  of  beneficiaries  are  identified:  (i)  recipients  of  the  training  vouchers,  
(ii) recipients of contracted training in priority skill areas, (iii) recipients of government support for 
training  in  selected  private  institutions,  and  (iv)  associated  effects  of  improved  training  and 
instructional materials in the four priority skill areas. In total, 20,000 students are expected to be 
trained. Utilization rates are likely to be high because project skill areas were carefully selected 
after extensive consultation on current labor market supply and demand and investment plans. 

34. 
Based on conservative assumptions, such carefully targeted skills training can increase 
monthly  wages  by  KN200,000.  Assuming  that  70%  of  beneficiaries  of training  provided  during 
the project will utilize their learned skills in the labor market within a short time, this translates to 
an  average  annual  earnings  increment  of  approximately  $200  per  year.  Estimating  these 
benefits over 20 years and based on the total project cost of $24.8 million yields an economic 
internal rate of return of 15.2%. 

35. 
Other benefits not included in these calculations are (i) improved gender distribution in 
TVET  as  a  consequence  of  GAP  activities,  (ii)  improved  quality  and  relevance  of  teaching  in 
other skill areas as a consequence of teacher training and workplace experience, (iii) improved 
TVET  institution  management  as  a  consequence  of  management-related  human  resource 
development, and (iv) improved governance due to increased private sector involvement.  

36. 
Financial  sustainability.  The  project  should  be  financially  sustainable  as  the  bulk  of 
expenditures  do  not  carry  on  beyond  the  end  of  the  project.  Recurrent  expenditures  such  as 
equipment maintenance cost can be absorbed by additional revenues from government funding, 
student  fees,  tailored  training  for  enterprises,  and  rental  of  training  venues.  Fully  90%  of 
nongovernment revenues can be used at the discretion of the institution management (e.g., to pay 
teachers  for  additional  hours,  instructional  materials,  repair  and  maintenance,  security).  The 
government plans to move to a unit-cost-based funding system, which will be designed as part of 
the project. The ESDF financing plan, however, shows that during FY2010–FY2016 the proportion 
of total sector expenditure allocated to TVET is expected to rise (Table 4 in the financial analysis) 

 

 8 

and the expenditure per student is expected to rise compared with other subsectors (Table 5 in 
the financial analysis).9 

37. 
The  project  will  increase  the  labor  market  relevance  of  the  TVET  system  and  improve 
the policy framework governing TVET institutions; both of these will improve the sustainability of 
the TVET sector by making it better serve the national social and economic development needs, 
the knowledge and skill learning needs of young people, and labor market demand. 

38. 
Project financing. The project involves a total government contribution of $1.8 million, 
mostly  in  the  form  of  taxes  and  duties.  The  total  incremental  recurrent  cost  (salaries  and 
imputed rent and utilities) is $11,200 per year. This annual government contribution ranges from 
0.1%  to  0.2%  of  the  total  TVET  recurrent  budget,  assuming  ESDF  spending  projections.  This 
suggests the project costs are sustainable.   

39. 
Incremental operating costs. Incremental operating costs will be associated with new 
dormitory  and  classrooms  financed  under  the  project.  The  total  investment  in  equipment, 
furnishings,  dormitory  rooms,  classrooms,  and  vehicles  is  $10.5  million.  Assuming  that 
operating  costs  and  repairs  and  maintenance  equal  8%  of  the  investment,  the  incremental 
recurrent  cost  will  be  $840,000  annually  beginning  in  FY2015,  which  amounts  to  9.4%  of  the 
total  government  nonwage  recurrent  budget  for  the  subsector  (assuming  ESDF  spending 
projections),  a  figure  that  declines  to  6.4%  by  FY2016  due  to  the  rising  TVET  budget.  In 
succeeding years, this proportion is likely to fall as the government budget rises. This, plus the 
fact  that  TVET  institutions  can  charge  tuition  fees  to  help  cover  costs,  suggests  the  project's 
incremental operating costs are sustainable. 

B. 

Governance 

40. 
Financial  management  and  procurement  capacity  assessments  found  that  while  MOE 
has the capacity to carry out the project, it will encounter significant challenges. Of key concern 
is the large number (and cumulative size) of projects managed by MOE, including several ADB 
projects, the World Bank's Second Education Development Project, and the recently approved 
multidonor  Education  for  All  Fast  Track  Initiative.  Combined,  these  projects  will  place  further 
strain  on  MOE's  ability  to  carry  out  procurement  and  disbursements  in  a  timely  and  effective 
manner.  The  financial  management  assessment  identifies  lack  of  capacity  and  insufficient 
staffing  in  the  accounting  and  financial  control  division  of  MOE's  Department  of  Finance  and 
financial information management system. Of particular concern is the lack of standardization in 
the use of accounting software across different MOE projects.   
 
41.  MOE indicates that it is addressing the capacity issue by increasing the number of staff 
in  its  accounting  and  financial  control  division.  It  has  created  several  new  positions  and  has 
already filled some. The World Bank will be undertaking a financial management assessment of 
the  education  sector  later  this  year.  The  project  will  provide  accounting  staff  for  the  project 
implementation  unit;  train  staff  in  financial  planning,  accounting,  auditing,  and  control;  and 
implement  a  performance-based  planning  and  budgeting  system  using  the  cost  norms  to  be 
developed under the project. The financial management assessment is in the PAM.  
 
The  procurement  capacity  assessment  found  that  while  TVED  has  experience  in 
42. 
procuring  goods,  it  lacks  experience  in  procuring  works  and  services.  The  project  will  provide 
support  to  supplement  procurement  capacity,  including  training  in  the  preparation  of  bid 
documents  for  civil  works  and  bid  evaluations,  and  site  management  and  monitoring  of  civil 
works implementation.

43. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  MOE.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM. 
 
C. 

Poverty and Social 

for 

Gender and development. The project is designed to address key constraints to girls' 
44. 
access to TVET and includes a GAP to facilitate and promote increased girls’ participation and 
benefits  from  the  project.  The  GAP  addresses  access  and  equity  issues  by  setting  gender 
quotas  for  training  in  the  three  nontraditional  priority  skill  areas,  dormitory  spaces,  voucher 
recipients, and other training opportunities. The GAP includes the following targets and design 
features:  (i)  quota  of  girls  making  up  20%  of  enrolments  in  three  nontraditional  priority  skill 
areas;  (ii)  25%  of  vouchers  reserved  for  girls;  (iii)  50%  of  dormitory  spaces  reserved  for  girls;  
(iv) targets of women making up 20% of TVET teachers, and 40% of trainees in the specialist 
skill  contracting  program  and  50%  in  the  skills  contracting  program;  (v)  implementation  of  a 
wage  subsidy  scheme 
to  promote  poststudy 
employment;  (vi)  social  marketing  to  promote  nontraditional  skills  and  trades  among  girls;  
(vii)  provision  of  gender  training  to  stakeholders,  and  (viii)  development  of  monitoring  and 
evaluation indicators to track GAP implementation. 
 
45. 
Ethnic groups. An ethnic group development plan was prepared to ensure integration of 
ethnic  groups'  needs  and  interests  in  project  outputs,  and  ensure  ethnic  group  access  and 
participation. Key features include (i) ethnic group enrolment in certificate and diploma education 
in the four priority skill areas reaches 20%; (ii) at least 30% of vouchers and dormitory spaces are 
reserved for ethnic students; (iii) the social marketing campaign is targeted to ethnic communities 
to encourage TVET and present positive role models, especially in nontraditional skill areas; and 
(iv) ethnicity sensitivity training is provided to project stakeholders. 
 
D. 

female  voucher-recipient  graduates 

Safeguards 

The involuntary resettlement category is C, as civil works is limited to upgrading TVET 
46. 
institution  facilities  and  constructing  new  buildings  within  existing  boundaries,  which  will  not 
require  land  acquisition  or  resettlement.  The  indigenous  peoples'  categorization  is  B,  as  the 
voucher  program  and  the  construction  of  dormitories  will  directly  benefit  ethnic  groups.10  The 
environmental  categorization  is  C.  During  operation,  the  automotive  workshop  will  ensure 
proper disposal of hazardous waste such as engine oil. During construction of the dormitories, 
the contractor will keep noise and dust within locally acceptable levels, as well as manage fill, 
excavated  material,  and  solid  waste  in  a  manner  that  does  not  create  a  permanent  impact. 
Water supply in the dormitories will meet national drinking water quality standards.   
 
E. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

47.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in  the  risk  assessment  and  risk  management  plan.11  The  major  risks  are  that  the  government 
fails to keep its commitment to ESDF TVET targets, the supply of appropriately trained teachers 
is  not  adequate  to  improve  TVET  quality,  and  the  poor  social  perception  of  TVET  means  that 
employers  and  potential  students  are  not  interested  in  TVET.  These  risks  are  all  addressed 
under the project. In summary, the benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the risks.

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

48. 
The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project will conform to all

gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM 
and  grant  documents.  The  government  has  agreed  with  ADB  on  certain  covenants  for  the 
project, which are set out in the grant agreement. 
 
49. 
ADB will not disburse grant proceeds for the construction of dormitories or procurement 
of  equipment  for  any  given  public  TVET  institution  until  such  institution  has  established  an 
advisory board and prepared an institutional improvement plan, both to the satisfaction of ADB.  
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

50. 
I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, under the provision 
of  Article  35.1  of  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  I  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the 
grant not exceeding $23,000,000 to the Lao People's Democratic Republic from ADB’s Special 
Funds  resources  for  the  Strengthening  Technical  and  Vocational  Education  and  Training 
Project, on terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the 
draft grant agreement presented to the Board.
